Graphical abstract The kinetics of the CH4/O2 reaction was studied in lean conditions on Natural-Gas-Vehicle Pd-doped LaMnO3 catalysts. The impact of the method for Pd incorporation, sol–gel vs. impregnation, has been examined. The calcination temperature to obtain the perovskite structure turned out to be a key to determine the strength of the interaction between Pd and LaMnO3. Steady-state kinetic measurements at 400 °C have been modeled according to a single site or a dual site reaction mechanism representative of the cooperation between Pd and surface lattice oxygen species supplied by the support material. Impregnated catalysts are found sensitive to particle sintering inducing a deterioration of the metal-support interface. On the contrary, aging leads to strenghening of the metal-support interaction on sol–gel Pd catalysts which promotes methane conversion notably near three-way operating conditions. Keywords Methane combustion NGV three-way catalyst Palladium Perovskite Kinetics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Palladium is a metal of choice in the catalytic combustion of methane in lean conditions. In the past three decades, numerous investigations dealt with the kinetics of this reaction and found that PdO acts as active phase to activate the C–H bond scission in these typical operating conditions [1–5]. Despite numerous studies, the engineering of active sites and related reaction mechanisms are still the subject of discussion combining both experimental and theoretical approaches [2,6–9]. Indeed, the kinetics of the CH4/O2 reaction is sensitive to the operating conditions, e.g. temperature, partial pressure of oxygen, and strongly depends on the adsorptive properties of the catalytic active sites with competitions inducing changes in adsorbates composition which can alter both catalytic activity and selectivity, i.e. undesired CO formation in rich atmosphere [10,11]. This reaction also appears structure sensitive with a particle size effect on the reaction rate in large excess of oxygen [12,13]. Kinetic models elaborated for three-way catalysts are more scarcity and predict in fuel rich a strong inhibition of methane adsorption at high CO coverage [14]. A key point lies in the thermal stability of PdO especially far from lean conditions and at high temperature which favor its decomposition into metallic Pd species. Easy and fast interconversion between Pd and PdO makes difficult the identification of active sites [15]. Based on this, various proposals arose in the past regarding the involvement of metallic Pd0 sites [6,16], oxidic PdO sites [4,17,18], mixed Pd-PdO phase [19,20] or strong Pd-LaMnO3 interface [21]. Cimino et al. [22] found that the formation of metastable PdO x phase over metallic Pd particles upon their reoxidation would the most active phase. In fact, the particular catalytic behavior of palladium is linked to the Pd-PdO transition and the influence that the size of the metallic palladium clusters or in oxide form can have on their reactivity and their stability. They correspond to different reaction pathways earlier discussed [23]. The C–H bond scission, as key elementary step for methane activation on bare metallic Pd surfaces, proceeds. Homolytic H-abstraction on O-saturated Pd surface leads to the formation of adsorbed CH3 and OH groups. On the other hand, heterolytic C–H bond cleavage occurs on PdO involving Pd2+ and vicinal O2– site pairs. This latter configuration corresponds to more stable transition state that can explain larger turn-over-rates. Interestingly, some similarities appear on pre-reduced Pd/α-Al2O3 [24]. Indeed, Hicks et al. relate the structure-sensitivity of the CH4/O2 reaction in stoichiometric conditions to the reactivity of different intermediate oxygen species depending on the O-coverage. On the other hand, the trend observed contradicts previous observations emphasizing the superiority of PdO for this reaction. Indeed, these authors obtained increasing turn-over-frequencies from PdO to Pd0. The higher catalytic properties of Pd0 compared to PdO has been also pointed out by Lyubovsky and Pfefferle on Pd/α-Al2O3 [6]. Nowadays, there is a renewed interest for this catalytic application in connection with environmental concerns regarding the substitution of liquid fuels by less harmful natural gas for heavy and light duty vehicle engines. Indeed, lower NO x and almost no particulate are emitted from Natural Gas Vehicle (NGV) fueled engines. However, the abatement of trace amount of methane in exhaust combustion gases is a pre-requisite because of the global warming potential of CH4 almost 20 times higher than that of CO2. Basically, NGV three-way catalysts run near stoichiometric conditions with alternate lean/rich cycles. Gasoline and diesel exhaust gas differ from their oxygen concentration. However, in both cases the sensitivity to catalyst deactivation is a significant drawback because of the weak thermal stability of PdO and a high sensibility to particle sintering at high temperature in the presence of steam. As a matter of fact, gain in stability can be obtained when PdO is dispersed on a substrate containing oxygen vacancies [25,26]. Indeed, Pd(I) like species were found stabilized on ceria-zirconia mixed oxides and then originating improved catalytic performances [26]. González-Marcos et al., found three-way catalytic performances on Pd/Ce0.68Zr0.32O2 compatible with the coexistence of two active Pd species, i.e. Pd(I) species at low temperature while Pd0 would act at high temperature [27]. In some extent, different kinetic behaviors can occur on Pd/Al2O3-CeO2 related to the Pd-PdO and Pd-CeO2 interfaces. Small metallic Pd particles combined with reactive oxygen from ceria outperform the performances related to preferential Pd0-PdO interaction [16]. Distinct reactions pathways over Pd/CeO2 were suggested depending on the oxidation state of palladium with cooperation between metallic Pd particles and oxygen lattice from CeO2 [28]. Some improvements in thermal stability were also obtained on Pd-doped perovskites for which a comparable approach can be envisioned taking peculiar Pd-perovskite interaction into account [29]. By way of illustration Pd-based YFeO3±δ three-way catalysts prepared by flame-spray pyrolysis did not reveal the presence of solid solution but preferential segregation of PdO onto the perovskite structure. Interestingly, aging under cycling conditions at 850 °C induced sharp catalytic improvements ascribed to hexagonal to orthorhombic phase transition accompanied with the formation of metallic Pd particles [29]. This study illustrates the impact of the method used for palladium addition to the perovskite substrate on the catalytic behavior during the methane combustion mainly in lean conditions. Indeed, previous studies found that the experimental protocol for the preparation of Pd-substituted perovskites influences the coordination state of palladium stabilized as PdO or in octahedral coordination in the perovskite lattice [30,31]. Stoichiometric LaMnO3 composition have been selected. Such composition has been found among the most thermally stable and exhibits remarkable catalytic activity in methane combustion [32,33]. Subsequent combination with palladium broadens the operating window thanks to the dual site nature of this catalyst [22]. Palladium has been incorporated through a one pot method, during the sol–gel synthesis, or according to a sequential approach, i.e. wet impregnation. Both methods lead to preferential stabilization of cationic Pd n + species inside the perovskite structure or surface PdO aggregates highligthing respectively strong and weak Pd-LaMnO3 interactions. The CH4/O2 reaction has been investigated on pre-reduced and aged catalysts after exposure to steam at 750 °C. The kinetic data were compared on the basis of mono- or bi-functional reaction mechanisms where the active sites are respectively only composed of Pd atoms or in combination with reactive oxygen species from the perovskite and/or PdO in the vicinity of Pd0. Through this approach, it will be suggested that kinetics can be a useful tool to probe changes induced by thermal aging and select, among the two experimental approaches used for Pd incorporation, the most appropriate. The beneficial effect ascribed to the growth of the Pd-LaMnO3 interface upon aging on the catalytic properties will be emphasized preferentially on one-pot samples compared to impregnated catalysts revealing their superiority in more representative three-way operating conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Parent LaMnO3 perovkites and composites LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 structures were prepared according to a classical citric method based upon the sol–gel route proposed by Taguchi et al. [34] (see Scheme S1 in supplementary information (SI)). For LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 composition, a one-pot synthesis strategy was implemented consisting in the dissolution of nitrate precursor salts supplied by Sigma Aldrich, i.e. La(NO3)3·6H2O (433.01 g/mol, purity: 99.999 %) and Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (251.01 g/mol, purity ≥ 97.0 %), in the presence of Pd(NO3)2·2H2O (266.46 g/mol, ∼40 % Pd). The characteristics of the precursor salts are more detailed in SI. Afterwards, citric acid (CA) was added taking the molar ratio of CA/La + Mn + Pd = 1 into account. The solution thus obtained was evaporated at 60 °C under reduced pressure till obtaining a viscous gel. The gel was dried in static conditions at 80 °C for 24 h. The dry solid precursor was heated at 300 °C to promote the exothermic decomposition of nitrates. Finally, a calcination under flow air conditions was carried out at 600 °C or 800 °C for 8 h with a temperature ramp of 2 °C/min. This procedure was also implemented for undoped-Pd perovskites. The samples were respectively labeled LaMnO3-C600, LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600, LaMnO3-C800 and LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800. A sequential method was also implemented for Pd incorporation consisting in a classical wet impregnation of LaMnO3-C600 and LaMnO3-C800 in an excess of solvent with corresponding amount for obtaining the same 1 wt% Pd composition. The impregnated precursors were dried in the same aforementioned conditions and calcined in a air flow for 8 h at 400 °C. The samples were respectively labeled Pt/LaMnO3-C600 and Pt/LaMnO3-C800. Elemental composition was obtained from X-ray Fluorescence analysis (see Table S1 in SI). 2.2 Bulk and surface physicochemical characterization Powder X-ray diffraction analysis was performed on a Bruker AXS D8 advance diffractometer in Bragg-Brentanamo geometry fitted with a LynxEye Super Speed detector. Data were recorded with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm, 40 kV, 30 mA) on the 2θ range 10°-80° with 2θ step of 0.02°. The reducibility of calcined catalysts was studied from hydrogen temperature-programmed-reduction (H2-TPR) experiment in a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 apparatus from room temperature (RT) to 1000 °C with a constant heating rate dT/dt = 10 °C.min−1. Sample weight of 50 mg catalyst was exposed to a flow of 5 vol% hydrogen diluted in argon. H2 consumption was measured thanks to a thermal conductivity detector. A calibration curve relating the integrated surface of the signal to the hydrogen consumption made it possible to calculate the H/(Mn + Pd) ratio. Oxygen Temperature Programmed Desorption (O2-TPD) experiments were performed with the same Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 apparatus. Prior to O2-TPD measurements, 50 mg catalyst samples were exposed to pure oxygen flow (5 mL/min) from ambient temperature up to 600 °C, with a constant heating rate of 10 °C/min, and kept at this final temperature for 1 h. After cooling down at RT, the catalyst was purged under helium flow and then gradually heated to 1000 °C with a constant temperature gradient of 10 °C/min. The composition of the outlet gas mixture was monitored by gas chromatography and mass spectrometry (MS) (m/z = 32). The normalized intensity of the MS signal was calibrated at various partial pressures of oxygen to estimate the amount of oxygen released from the surface and the bulk. The high-resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy (HR-STEM) was performed on a ThermoFisher Scientific TITAN Themis 300 microscope. The microscope was equipped with high brightness Schottky field effect gun and a probe aberration corrector. A super-X windowless 4 quadrant SDD (silicon drift detector) detection system was used for the STEM-EDS (Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy - Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy) mapping. STEM observations were carried out with an accelerating voltage of 300 kV with a spot size of about 500 pm, semi-convergence angle of 18 mrad and probe current of approximately 100 pA. High angle annular dark field (HAADF) images were recorded with collection angles ranging from 50 mrad to 200 mrad. STEM-EDS mapping was performed with dwell time of 15 μs per pixel with continuous scanning over multiple frames for a total time of 10–15 min per acquisition. Quantification of the STEM-EDS hyper-spectral maps was performed using the Cliff-Lorimer method and applying an absorption correction. Nitrogen physisorption isotherms were recorded at −196 °C on a Micromeritics Tristar analyzer. Before analysis, the samples were evacuated under vacuum for 4 h at 200 °C. Specific surface area (SSA) was determined from the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) theory and pore size distribution thanks to the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) theory. H2-titration measurements were performed on the same Micromeritics analyser by using a pulse technique at 100 °C with diluted H2 in argon corresponding to H2 partial pressure below 10-2 atm [35]. Pd dispersion was calculated assuming H/Pd = 1. Prior to chemisorption, the samples were pre-reduced in pure H2 at 250 °C and outgassed under argon. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) measurements were performed on a Kratos Axis Ultra spectrometer equipped with a monochromatized Al Kα source (15 mA, 14 kV) and a charge compensation gun. C 1 s photopeak, with binding energy (B.E.) of 285.0 eV, was used as internal reference for the calibration of Pd 3d, Mn 2p, O 1s and La 3d B.E. values. Semiquantitative analysis was carried out using the scientific software CasaXPS. 2.3 Catalytic measurements Preliminary Temperature-Programmed-Reaction experiments (TPR) were performed in a fixed bed flow reactor at atmospheric pressure between 120 and 600 °C with a gradient temperature of 5 °C.min−1. The Gas Hourly Space Velocity was fixed at 60 L.h−1.g−1. Prior to TPR experiments, the catalysts were pre-reduced at 250 °C in pure H2. Catalytic testings were performed in lean and stoichiometric conditions respectively with inlet gas composed of 1000 ppm CH4 and 5 vol% O2 diluted in He while more respresentative inlet gas composition was chosen for stoichiometric conditions with 1000 ppm CH4, 500 ppm CO, 2000 ppm NO, 1250 ppm O2, 8 vol% CO2 and 1.0 vol% H2O diluted in He. The outlet concentrations of reactants and products were measured by using an Agilent 490 Micro Gas Chromatograph fitted with a thermal conductivity detector. The TPR experiments were reproduced on aged catalysts after exposure to a gas mixture composed of 5 vol% O2 and 10 vol% H2O at 750 °C for 4 h. Steady-state high-throughput kinetic measurements were performed on the REALCAT platform in a Flowrence unit supplied by Avantium. 16 parallel quartz fixed-bed microreactors (d = 2 mm) were installed, equipped with sampling system corresponding to a 16-ports multi position valve. This system was suitable for analyzing the composition of the gas mixtures leaving each reactor using an Agilent 7890 gas chromatograph. 30 mg catalyst with average grain size of 100 μm were introduced in each reactor. Inlet gas mixture was composed of 750–3000 ppm CH4 with 5 vol% O2 in the presence or in the absence of 10 vol% H2O in the temperature range 350–600 °C. Two similar series were carried out first on pre-reduced samples and then on aged samples according to the aforementioned conditions. Before kinetic measurements, the catalyst was pre-reduced in hydrogen at 250 °C to stabilize metallic Pd particles. The space velocity for each reactor was maintained constant at 60 L.h−1.g−1. Methane conversion X CH 4 was maintained below 5 % insuring differential operating conditions. Based on this, the specific reaction rate was calculated from Eq. (1) where F CH 4 , 0 was the inlet molar flow rate of methane and W the mass of catalyst. (1) r = F CH 4 , 0 X CH 4 W ( m o l s - 1 g - 1 ) Preliminary experiments shown that external diffusion should not occur significantly as different experiments by varying the sample weight, keeping constant the gas hourly space velodity, led to comparable methane conversions. CH4 combustion is exothermic and the heat released in the course of the reaction can induce a gradient temperature inside the porous structure of the grain then leading to concentration gradients. The maximum relative temperature deviation was estimated according to Eq. (S1) in SI as described elsewhere [36]. The dependence of the effectiveness of the catalyst η on the Weiss Prater Criterion was earlier described [37]. On this basis, the effectiveness of the catalyst η for non isothermal reactions was estimated thanks to the calculation of the modified Weisz-Prater criterion Φ given in Eq. (2) which accounted for the measured reaction rate (robs, mol.m−3.s−1), the concentration of methane in the gas phase (Cobs, mol.m−3), the effective diffusivity of CH4 (Deff,CH4, m2.s−1), and the characteristic length representing the volume to surface ratio (L, m). (2) Φ = h ϕ 2 = r obs L 2 C obs D eff , C H 4 Calculations detailed in SI showed that the effectiveness factor η tends to 1 consistent with low methane concentration diluted in He, and perovskite materials developing weak porosity. Hence the chemical regime prevailed in our operating conditions. 3 Results 3.1 Temperature-programmed CH4/O2 reaction experiments on Pd-doped LaMnO3 perovskites Preliminary catalytic measurements were performed on pre-reduced catalysts in H2 at 250 °C to insure a complete reduction of PdO into Pd0. Fig. S1 in SI shows that this pre-reductive thermal treatment did not alter the rhombohedral structure of LaMnO3. This observation agrees with previous observations showing extensive reduction process only above 500 °C [21]. A first TPR experiment on pre-reduced LaMnO3-C600, Pd/LaMnO3-C600 and LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 was performed in dry conditions under a flow containing 1000 ppm CH4 and 5 vol% O2. A second TPR experiment was repeated in the same operating conditions on in situ aged Pd-doped catalysts subjected to a thermal treatment at 750 °C in wet conditions (5 vol% O2 with 10 vol% H2O diluted in He). Methane conversion profiles vs. temperature are reported in Fig. 1 . The bare perovskite was found to be active. Despite methane conversion is delayed being significant above 420 °C. A rise in temperature leads to quasi-complete methane conversion near 590 °C consistently with previous observations [22]. A broadening of the conversion range is observed after Pd incorporation which agrees with previous observations explaining a possible cooperation between Pd and LaMnO3 [22] which could reflect the dual site nature of this catalyst. It is worth to note that the CH4 conversions measured on pre-reduced Pd/LaMnO3-C600 and LaMn0.098Pd0.02O3-C600 are comparable with no significant deviations. For impregnated Pd/LaMnO3 catalyst, thermal aging has a slight detrimental effect with a weak but detectable loss of CH4 conversion. In constrast, a gain in methane conversion is distinguishable on aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 below 470 °C, then a rise in temperature leads to quasi superimposed conversions. Such opposite trend observed on aged Pd/LaMnO3 and aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 catalysts reflects improved stabilizing effect of the perovskite when Pd is initially incorporated in the perovskite lattice during the sol gel synthesis [38]. For impregnated samples, the slight deactivation observed could results from the conjunction of loss of specific surface area and Pd dispersion. Eventhough metallic Pd particles are originally stabilized at the surface, subsequent reoxydation should occur in the presence of an excess of oxygen [13,39]. The thermal treatment at 750 °C can also destabilized PdO x species which can decompose into metallic Pd0 species. On this basis, it clearly appears that the catalytic behaviour of Pd-doped LaMnO3 can be governed by the PdO-Pd interconversion. In order to get more insights, the catalytic performance of pre-reduced and aged Pd-doped LaMnO3 were studied near the stoichiometry with more representative composition for the exhaust containing 1000 ppm CH4, 500 ppm CO, 2000 ppm NO, 1250 ppm O2, 8 vol% CO2 and 1.0 vol% H2O. In these operating conditions, all the pre-reduced catalysts would presumably exert more a metallic behaviour [40] compared to lean conditions for which the contribution of PdO itself cannot be ruled out [4]. Clearly, lower performances are observed in an oxygen-depleted environment likely due to the detrimental inhibiting effect of water [40] and also the high concentration of CO2 [4]. Indeed, Ribeiro et al. found a strong negative apparent order for CO2 when the concentration largely exceed 0.5 vol%. However, the most salient observation lies in the sharp increase in methane conversion on aged-LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 while the behaviour of aged and pre-reduced Pd/LaMnO3-C600 remains quasi-unchanged. As a matter of fact, these trends accentuate those observed in lean conditions with an excess of oxygen on aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 which emphasizes the importance of the method used for Pd incorporation driving different Pd-LaMnO3 interactions. 3.2 Steady-state kinetic study of the CH4/O2 reaction on Pd-doped perovskite catalysts: Impact the method for Pd incorporation Similarly, steady state kinetic measurements were performed on pre-reduced catalysts at 250 °C and reproduced on aged samples subjected to a thermal treatment at 750 °C under wet conditions as described. In that case, the study has been extended to sol gel and impregnated Pd/LaMnO3-C800 and LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800 with perovskite structure obtained after calcination at 800 °C. The influence of the partial pressure of methane p(CH4) on the reaction rate was studied at 400 °C in the range (0.75–3.0) × 10-3 atm keeping constant the inlet partial pressure of oxygen p(O2) = 0.05 atm. The influence of steam on the reaction rate was also checked at the same temperature with p(H2O) = 0.1 atm. The temperature dependence of the reaction rate has been examined in dry conditions (absence of steam) at fixed p(CH4) = 1.0 × 10-3 atm and p(O2) = 0.05 atm in the temperature range 350–400 °C for pre-reduced catalysts and 400–500 °C for aged catalysts. Part of the kinetic data are summarized in Table 1 to illustrate the impact of the protocol used for Pd addition on the catalytic properties in CH4 conversion, i.e. one pot vs. sequential approach, as well as the consequences of the thermal aging. The positive reaction order with respect to methane is consistent with previous investigations [3,18]. Previous study [23] also found a weak sensitivity of this parameter to changes in operating conditions from stoichiometric to lean conditions [23]. Let us note that reaction rate values recorded in dry conditions on pre-reduced and aged catalysts remain of the same order of magnitude, irrespective of the method used for Pd incorporation, which emphasizes a relatively good thermal stability. In contrast, a weak tolerance to steam exposure appears with a sharp decrease in the reaction rates. Previous studies clearly evidenced a pronounced inhibiting effect due to strong water adsorption [5,17]. Similarly, these evolutions seem weakly dependent on the protocol used for Pd addition. As a matter of fact, the temperature appears as the most critical parameters on the kinetics corresponding to significant changes observed on the pre-exponential factor (A) and the apparent activation energy (Eapp) of the reaction rate constant k on aged catalysts. The calculated values for Eapp are globally higher than those currently obtained on PdO [4,5]. Such trend was earlier pointed out on Pd/α-Al2O3 stabilized as PdO or metallic Pd state shifting from 73 to 157 kJ.mol−1 respectively [24]. A compensation effect is observed between the pre-exponential factor (A) and Eapp which explains the weak evolution on the reaction rate values obtained after aging. Nevertheless, opposite variations on these two kinetic parameters are noticeable on impregnated and one-pot samples. Indeed, aging leads to a joint decrease of the apparent activation energy (Eapp) and the pre-exponential factor (A) on aged Pd/LaMnO3-C600 and aged Pd/LaMnO3-C800. Conversely, the opposite trend is noticeable on aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 and aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800 with an increase of A and Eapp values. The entropic parameter A may depend on various parameters such as the density of active sites, the size and the morphology of palladium particles, the Pd-support interaction, the occurrence of inhibiting effect due to strong adsorption of reactants or products as observed in the presence of water. At first glance, the lowering of the pre-exponential factor on aged Pd/LaMnO3 samples could result from Pd particle sintering as reported elsewhere [41,42] due to weaker interactions with the support. The concomitant decrease in the apparent activation energy could be related to a structure-sensitive CH4/O2 reaction, previously assigned to the nature of reactive oxygen species [13,24], i.e. to the Pd0-PdO transition. On this basis, one can hypothesize that oxidation into larger PdO in Pd/LaMnO3 could occur more readily because of weaker Pd-support interaction. This could partly explain the decrease in Eapp in agreement with the aforementioned observations [4,5,24]. However, according to this explanation, the opposite variations on A and Eapp on aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 would reflect a redispersion of stabilized palladium species at the surface. The complexity in the evolutions observed on A and Eapp suggests that the discussion should not be restrained to palladium but also accounts for the contribution of the perovskite support in line with previous observations from TPR experiments (see Fig. 1). 3.3 Structural vs. Bulk reducibility and oxygen mobility of calcined Pd-doped LaMnO3 perovskites Physicochemical properties in this section concern essentially calcined catalysts to evaluate the impact of the calcination temperature on the structure and texture of the perovskite, in the presence and in the absence of palladium. The consequences on the reducibility of oxidic manganese and palladium species have been also examined. Particular attention was also paid to surface and bulk oxygen mobility in connection to surface and bulk heterogeneities likely to form according to the synthesis protocol. 3.3.1 Structural features from XRD analysis XRD patterns recorded on calcined samples are reported in Fig. 2 . Except LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 exhibiting an amorphous structure with no distinct reflections, all other patterns are dominated by the reflections assigned to the rhombohedral structure of LaMnO3 (PDF 04-012-5560). This is particularly evident for samples calcined at 800 °C, exhibiting higher crystallinity, with the characteritic peak splitting at 2θ = 32.5° and 32.8°. In fact, the main observations on diffractograms recorded on samples calcined at 600 °C are related to peaks broadening and simultaneous appearance of weak and broad reflections at 2θ = 28.9°, 31.0° and 59.9° which underline the formation of extra framework MnO x impurities (PDF 04-007-1841). Let us note that no characteristic reflection of PdO appears. Therefore, the calcination temperature seems to be a critical parameter because a pure structure without segregation is favored at 800 °C while a calcination at lower temperature induces segregation that could lead to the formation of cationic vacancies. The calcination temperature also originates changes in the porous structure. Indeed, calcination at 800 °C leads to a significant loss of specific surface and a contraction of the pore volume (see Table 2 ). 3.3.2 Reducibility of manganese species from H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments This technique is useful to evaluate the amount of Mn4+ which depends on the calcination temperature. As reported elsewhere, non-stoichiometric LaMnO3+δ structure with δ > 0 forms under air conditions, corresponding to Mn4+ composition higher than 20 % [43–45]. As reported, an increase of δ is expected by lowering the sintering temperature. Hence, an increase in Mn4+ concentration should occur on samples calcined at 600 °C compared to catalysts calcined at 800 °C. Experiments were performed on bare and Pd-doped calcined perovskites. H2-consumption profiles vs. temperature are reported in Fig. 3 on one-pot and impregnated Pd-doped samples. For sake of clarity, experiments on bare perovskites have been included to evaluate the influence of the calcination temperature on the reducibility of MnO x species and the ability of palladium to speed up surface and/or bulk reduction processes. In this latter case, the impact of the method for Pd incorporation should be visible because wet impregnation followed by moderate calcination temperature at 400 °C should lead to Pd species essentially distributed at the surface. In contrast, more homogeneous distribution of cationic palladium species in the perovskite lattice is expected in the particular case LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 catalysts. Starting from bare LaMnO3-C600 and LaMnO3-C800, two temperature ranges appear corresponding to the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ and the successive reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+. As aforementioned, the first reduction process should not drastically deteriorate the rhombohedral structure of LaMnO3. In contrast, a complete reduction and a loss of structural properties should occur above 600 °C accompanied with the segregation of La2O3 and MnO corresponding to atomic H/Mn ratio varying from 1 to 2 according to the Mn4+ content. An important feature appears when the calcination temperature for obtaining the perovskite structure is performed at 600 °C with an intensification of the low temperature H2 consumption. This observation agrees with more extensive formation of Mn4+ and cationic vacancies in the lattice structure consecutive to the exsolution of more reducible extra framework MnO x species [46]. The impact of palladium is more apparent on the one-pot LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 samples. Indeed, the high temperature signal strongly attenuates on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 reflecting a faster bulk reduction. On the other hand, this behaviour seems less pronounced on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800. These observations especially for one-pot samples highlight the role of metallic Pd0 species which form at low temperature and then can easily dissociate hydrogen. Subsequent hydrogen spill-over would promote the reduction of oxidic manganese species at much lower temperature. 3.3.3 Oxygen mobility from O2-temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) experiments O2-TPD is helpful to probe surface and bulk oxygen mobility and related reactivity. O2 desorption profiles vs. temperature in Fig. 4 match classical observations with weakly adsorbed oxygen [47] releasing the surface below 500 °C assigned to suprafacial oxygen desorption (α-oxygen). The α-oxygen desorption process increases in intensity with a rise of the specific surface area and appears more intense when the calcination proceeds at 600 °C for obtaining the perovsite structure. Subsequent comparisons with LaMnO3-C600 and Pd/LaMnO3-C600 shows that this low temperature process is promoted on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 which could reflect enhanced oxygen mobity from the perovskite thanks to an improved interaction with palladium compared to Pd/LaMnO3-C600 (see Table 2). It is worthwhile to note that a prominent signal appears at high temperature essentially reflecting the mobility of lattice oxygen species conventionally assigned to intrafacial oxygen desorption (β-oxygen). Gaseous oxygen released from PdO decomposition into Pd metal slightly contributes corresponding to nearly 10 % of high temperature desorption process and cannot be properly quantified due to strong overlapping with the β-oxygen desorption process. α-oxygen desorption is surface dependent and hardly detected on Pd/LaMnO3-C800 and on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800. On the other hand, β-oxygen desorption is more influenced by the nature of B cations reflecting the strength of the Mn-O bond. The low- and high-temperature O2-desorption ranges can be quantified taking into accoung the contribution of PdO decomposition on the β-oxygen desorption. Data in Table 2 provide useful information through the calculation of the normalized amount from β-oxygen desorption showing increasing values when the perovskite is calcined at 800 °C instead of 600 °C. XRD analysis clearly shows that amorphous structures obtained at 600 °C are transformed into well-crystalline samples at 800 °C. This observation agrees with earlier conclusions drawn by Alifanti et al. [48] who found weak surface oxygen mobility due to a loss of specific surface partly compensated by a faster bulk oxygen diffusion thanks to improved crystallinity. 3.4 Structural and surface changes induced by thermal aging Microcopy and surface analyses were carried out on calcined and aged samples. Indeed, the recovery of low amounts of aged samples from high-throughput catalytic measurements restricted extensive physicochemical characterization of aged samples. However, the collection of data from these two techniques provided useful information to relate surface properties to kinetic features. 3.4.1 High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) coupled to elemental mapping analysis HAADF-STEM is a useful technique to characterize low amont of active elements dispersed in an inorganic matrix which is typically our case by considering the distribution of low amount of palladium in LaMnO3 according to the preparation method. This technique is also suitable to evaluate the extent of redispersion/agglomeration processes taking place during aging. Intensity in HAADF images is proportional to the thickness, the density and the atomic number Z1.7. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopic measurements parallel to the HAADF imaging provides more accurate information illustrated in Figs. 5–7 . HAADF images in Fig. 5(a) and Fig. 5(c) reveal the porous and amorphous structure of calcined LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600. It is also obvious that Pd is highly dispersed in the perovskite matrix and only a small fraction of Pd particles can be observed by examing different images with Pd particle size lower than 2 nm. This observation suggests, a preferential stabilization of cationic Pd n + in octahedral coordination inside the perovskite lattice. Significant structural changes are discernible on aged-LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600. First, La and Mn seem more homogeneously distributed. Secondly small palladium aggregation takes place. Let us note that the comparison of HAADF images (see Fig. 5-(e)-(j)) at lower and higher magnifications show that Pd particles agglomerate within the crystalline perovskite matrix and their sizes vary between 2 and 10 nm. As seen in Fig. 6, calcined LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800 catalyst exhibits different features. As previously emphasized a significant crystallization occurs when the sample is calcined at 800 °C and the pore structure is no longer observed for this sample. Nonetheless the most significant change lies in the observation of much larger Pd aggregates on the calcined sample with sizes up 30 nm which suggest the occurrence of Pd n + segregation into more unstable PdO extraframework species during the protocol synthesis, i.e. calcination at 800 °C. Let us note that a calcination at 800 °C leads to stable structural features as subsequent aging at 750 °C does no longer induce discernible structural deteriorations both on the perovskite structure and also on the dispersion of palladium species. Finally, the comparison with Pd/LaMnO3-C600 is useful as in this latter case Pd is essentially localized at the surface. The final calcination at 400 °C should not induce significant bulk diffusion inside the perovskite lattice with no deterioration of the specific surface area. It is obvious that oxidic Pd species are well dispersed at the surface and the extent of aggregation seems limited with Pd particles sizes of approximately 2 nm to 10 nm. On aged Pd/LaMnO3-C600, larger palladium aggregates with size up to 15 nm or as small (1.5 nm) well-distributed particles within the crystalline perovskite grains. These observations do not emphasize strong particle sintering suggesting a relatively good stability of nano-sized Pd particles bonded the perovskite support on the calcined Pd/LaMnO3-C600. Particular attention has been also paid to the spacial distribution of Mn and La. Fig. 7(b) and (f) underlines on Pd/LaMnO3-C600 inhomogeneities in composition in lanthanum and manganese. Indeed, in some Mn-rich grains La appears segregated within 1 nm thick amorphous surface layer as well as in the PdO particles. Different regions have been explored at nanometer scale to check the variation on the La/Mn ratio. In order to increase the signal to noise ratio each EDS map has been segmented to regions of interest with sizes dependent on the field of view of the specific map and thus ranging between 15 × 15 nm2 to 300 × 300 nm2. The corresponding histograms are reported in Fig. 8 on calcined and aged catalysts revealing different changes in the La and Mn distribution. Indeed, narrow distribution of the La/Mn ratio on calcined and aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 is observable with average values of respectively to 1.10 ± 0.07 and 1.06 ± 0.04 showing slight changes after aging within the margin of error. The same trend also appears on the calcined and aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800 samples still observing a narrow distribution with La/Mn values of respectively 1.15 ± 0.08 and 1.23 ± 0.04. In contrast, different observations characterize Pd/LaMnO3-C600 with a broader distribution of the La/Mn ratio with an average value of 0.89 ± 0.10 emphasizing the presence of Mn-rich grains on calcined sample. Aging, changes significantly the La/Mn ratio on Pd/LaMnO3-C600 shifting towards higher La/Mn values. 3.4.2 Surface properties from XPS analysis XPS analysis provides more insights into the oxidation state of manganese and palladium, their relative composition at the surface and the changes observed on these two parameters on aged samples. La 3d, Mn 2p, O 1 s and Pd 3d photopeaks have been examined. Unchanged spectral features characterized La 3d with typical B.E. near 834 eV representative of the trivalent cation La3+ in the perovskite structure. Mn 2p and O 1 s photopeaks are reported in Figs. S2 and S3 in SI. O 1 s photopeaks are dominated by two components on calcined samples near 529 eV and 531 eV assigned respectively to oxygen lattice species (Olattice) and adsorbed oxygen species (Oads), i.e. O2 –, O- or OH groups. A weak and broad contribution has been isolated near 533 eV from peak decomposition which could correspond to oxygen from carbonates. This component increases on aged samples emphasizing possible interaction with gaseous CO2 formed in the course of the reaction and then reacting with surface OH groups and surface lattice oxygen O surf 2 - species. [48]. The intensity signal at 533 eV has been considered in the Oads component to calculate the Oads to Olattice ratio reported and compared in Table 3 . No appreciable variation on this ratio is discernible on calcined samples varying within the margin of error with no clear dependency on the specific surface area. Obviously, more significant evolutions arise on aged samples as the Oads/Olattice ratio increases more significantly on aged impregnated Pd/LaMnO3 samples and more marginally on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3. As a matter of fact, the most prominent evolutions come from the comparison of the Pd 3d photopeaks on calcined and aged samples (see Fig. 9 ). On calcined catalysts, B.E. values for the Pd 3d 5/2 photopeak near 337.0 eV are comparable according to the accuracy emphasizing the presence of Pd2+. Calculations of the atomic Pd/La + Mn ratio in Table 3 lead to the highest value for LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800. This surface Pd-enrichment likely into more reducible oxidic Pd species seems consistent with the highest metallic Pd dispersion obtained from H2-titration. For calcined LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 and Pd/LaMnO3-C600, Pd/La + Mn ratio is comparable but some divergencies appear with the evolution observed on the Pd dispersion. Indeed, the very low dispersion on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 compared to that obtained on Pd/LaMnO3-C600 reflects a preferential stabilization of less reducible oxidic palladium species in the perovskite lattice in agreement with STEM-EDS observations. Aging induced significant changes in spectral features. First, no signal appears distinctly on the Pd 3d photopeak for Pd/LaMnO3-C800. Strong perturbations also appear for Pd/LaMnO3-C600 and on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 as a predominant contribution arises at lower B.E. values ∼ 335 eV characteristic of metallic Pd0 species. This contribution can be reasonably explained by the reductive thermal treatment prior to the reaction. Thermal decomposition of PdO during aging at 750 °C can also contribute to the growth of metallic Pd species. Jointly, the former contribution near 336.8 eV assigned to Pd2+ strongly attenuates while an additional high B.E. contribution appears near 337.6 eV which has been previously assigned to an increase of the oxidation state of Pd n + with n > 2 or the stabilization of isolated cationic palladium in specific coordination with the surface structure of the substrate [49,50]. Jointly these changes in oxidation state of palladium are accompanied with opposite variations on the Pd/La + Mn ratio. Indeed, this ratio slightly grows on aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 while it decreases on aged Pd/LaMnO3-C600. On the other hand, the Pd/La + Mn ratio remains quasi-unchanged on aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800. This relative stability seems in agreement with previous HAADF-STEM analysis with no discernible growth of Pd particles on aged samples. Concomitant evolutions of the La/Mn ratio are noticeable. As seen in Table 3, La/Mn > 1 underlines slight La-rich surfaces on calcined samples except on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 exhibiting Mn-rich surface. Interestingly, the La/Mn ratio converges to comparable values on aged samples. This tendency seems in relative agreement with EDS analysis. Indeed, comparable evolutions are observed on the La/Mn ratio slightly shifting to higher values after aging. Parallel to these observations interesting comparisons can be established with the evolution observed on the Mn4+/Mn3+ ratio. Clearly, strong deviations are observable on impregnated Pd/LaMnO3-C600 and one-pot LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 samples which emphasize a much greater Mn4+ concentration on calcined samples. This observation agrees with expected increase in the oxygen stoichiometry in LaMnO3+ δ when the calcination proceeds at low temperature [43–45]. Interestingly, the convergence observed on the La/Mn ratio on aged samples coincides with that observed on Mn4+/Mn3+ which also tends to comparable values on aged samples. Such comparisons highligth significant changes which could be associated to a progressive suppression of segregated surface MnO x species finding a stoichiometry typical of pure LaMnO3 perovskite on aged samples. 4 Discussion This study illustrates the importance of the method used, when adding Pd to LaMnO3, on the kinetics of the CH4/O2 reaction. Two protocols have been implemented with palladium directly introduced during the sol–gel process and a two-step procedure after obtaining the perovskite structure through a classical wet impregnation. The chemical inertness of CH4 implies high operating temperatures for a complete methane abatement which can alter long-term catalyst stability. Particular attention was paid to thermal aging at 750 °C in wet conditions in the presence of 5 vol% O2 and 10 vol% H2O. The joint detrimental effects of water and temperature have been previously ascribed to particle sintering and surface reconstructions [41,42]. The instability of PdO, recognized as active phase, is associated with its decomposition into metal at high temperature above 750 °C. The particularity of perovskite support can interfere and drastically modify the catalyst behavior as previously demonstrated on YFeO3± δ perovskite doped with palladium [30]. Initially, PdO was found segregated onto the orthohombic structure of YFeO3±δ. Thermal aging at 850 °C in cycling conditions led the authors to the conclusion that more active systems would be assigned to metallic Pd particles dispersed onto reconstructed hexagonal perovskite structure. On this basis, an important point deals with the impact of the preparation method of Pd-doped LaMnO3 catalysts governing the extent of surface reconstructions taking place during aging at 750 °C. In fact, these ones can determine the strength of Pd-LaMnO3 interface as well as the oxidation state of Pd species influencing their kinetic behavior. Steady-state rate measurements were performed on pre-reduced and aged catalysts in an excess of gaseous oxygen at 400 °C. It appears that Pd-doped LaMnO3 are weakly sensitive to deactivation and this thermal resistance to deactivation seems independent of the mode of Pd incorporation. Despite the weak evolutions observed on the specific rate, strong deviations are observed on the apparent activation energy Eapp and the pre-exponential factor A on aged samples. A compensation effect explains the weak evolution on the specific reaction rates but remarkable trends lie in the opposite changes on A and Eapp observed on Pd/LaMnO3 and LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 catalysts. As emphasized in Table 1, the apparent activation energies Eapp and the pre-exponential factors A of the reaction rate constant jointly increase on aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 catalysts. Conversely, theses two parameters decrease on aged Pd/LaMnO3. Several factors could explain these contradictory variations associated with the modification of the density of the palladium sites, the size and morphology of the palladium particles, the strength of the Pd-LaMnO3 interface and the oxidation state of the palladium related to different scenarios involving metallic Pd particles saturated with adsorbed oxygen species or partially oxidized to bulk PdO. This would coincide to different C–H bond activation pathways, suggested from combined kinetic and DFT studies [23], shifting from a homolytic C–H bond scission on a Pd atom-oxygen(*-O*) site pairs, on metallic Pd sites covered by chemisorbed O atoms, to heterolytic bond breaking on Pd2+–O2- site pairs in PdO. Based on this, an important question arises related to the robustness of kinetic models to predict these surface changes. 4.1 Nature and evolution of the Pd-LaMnO3 interface during aging: Impact of the method for Pd incorporation It clearly appears that the weak evolutions on the specific reaction rates measured on pre-reduced catalysts at 250 °C cannot be simply explained by the sole evolution observed on the metallic Pd dispersion of pre-reduced Pd/LaMnO3 and LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 varying from 0.3 to 28.2. Indeed, the fluctuations observed on the reaction rates measured on pre-reduced catalysts are of the order of a factor 2. STEM-HAADF analyses on calcined samples provide complementary information which differ from those obtained from Pd dispersion. This is particularly true for LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 characterized by an extremely low capacity to adsorb H2 because most of isolated oxidic Pd n + would be embedded in the perovskite structure remaining unreduced. This is consistent with a weak detection of PdO particles from STEM-HAADF analysis and most of them are characterized by particle PdO size below 2 nm. In contrast, the examination of the calcined LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800, exhibiting the highest metallic dispersion, leads to more distinct observation of PdO particles in number eventhough their particle sizes vary in a broader range up to 30 nm. As earlier suggested [5], the stability and related reducibility of PdO clusters can be influenced by their particle size as small PdO x crystallites will exhibit higher stability related to a stronger Pd-O bond than on larger crystallites. As a consequence, the decrease of the band gap energy on small PdO x crystallites will decrease the surface density of oxygen vacancies on PdO x . On this basis, assuming complete reoxidation of the pre-reduced Pd particles to PdO during the reaction in excess oxygen without alteration of their size, then rate enhancement would be expected on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800 and Pd/LaMO3 in a large extent. In practice, the weak evolutions observed on the reaction rate measured on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 and LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800 (6.3 × 10-8 vs. 8.9 × 10-8 mol.s−1.g−1) does not match with this explanation except if changes in morphology occur assigned to a predominant distribution of less reactive PdO (100) facets instead of the most reactive Pd(101) facets at the surface of polycrystalline PdO particles [23]. This comparison at least emphasizes the complexity of the system associated to the participation of the support. Indeed, the strong difference in the metallic dispersion mentioned on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 and LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800 is not related to an exsolution process during the pre-reduction step because the structure of the perovskite under temperature conditions is preserved. It must therefore be admitted that calcination at 800 °C to obtain the rhombohedral structure of the perovskite during the preparation procedure does not allow the accomodation of Pd2+ cations to in the crystal lattice of the perovskite in octahedral coordination. It is also obvious that the calcination temperature used to obtain the perovskite structure during the protocol synthesis drastically changes the specific surface area and the surface composition. Clearly, this last parameter is critical in determining the nature and the strength of interaction with palladium as a function of surface Mn composition. Indeed the La/Mn values matches with the stoichiometry for the perovskite when calcined at 800 °C. On the other hand, extensive surface segregation of manganese oxide, corresponding to low La/Mn ratio and high concentration of Mn4+, evidenced from XPS and STEM-HAADF analysis, proceeds when the calcination is performed at 600 °C. On this basis, Pd/LaMnO3-C600 and LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 are much more sensitive to thermal aging at 750 °C with La/Mn ratio shifting to comparable values obtained on Pd/LaMnO3-C800 and LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800 emphasizing the suppression of the surface Mn-enrichment and the stabilization of Mn3+. It seems obvious that surface reconstructions taking place on pre-reduced LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 during aging result from the redispersion at the surface of metallic and oxidic Pd species in conjunction with surface change of Mn reaching the stoichiometric composition of the perovskite. All these observations show that exposure at high temperature at 800 °C leads to stable surface starting from catalysts characterized by strong difference according to the method used for Pd incorporation. These changes on the surface structure open the question if they can be reconciled through an unique reaction mechanism or on the contrary if dynamics changes of Pd and Mn composition would correspond to different reaction mechanisms. 4.2 Reaction mechanism of the CH4/O2 reaction vs. changes in surface structure A second step consists in evaluating the impact of these changes on the kinetics thanks to the exploitation of steady-tate reaction rates in order to discriminate the most probable reaction mechanism and verify if the predicted rate expressions based on fitted kinetic and thermodynamic parameters match with the evolution observed on the surface properties of Pd-based catalysts. 4.2.1 First discrimination from a theoretical approach As earlier emphasized, the kinetics of the CH4/O2 reaction and related reaction mechanisms have been essentially developed on PdO. In our operating conditions, Pd-based catalysts have been pre-reduced to get metallic Pd particles preserving the perovskite structure. In a first approach, a single site reaction mechanism involving only Pd0 sites can be envisioned. This suggestion agrees with previous studies from kinetics, isotopic methods and DFT calculations examining different reactions pathways for the C–H bond breaking during the CH4 reaction on Pd involving bare Pd sites, Pd sites saturated by chemisorbed oxygen and PdO clusters [23]. Elementary steps selected in the two mechanism proposals i.e. mechanisms I(a) and I(b), (see scheme 1 ) for methane oxidation have been earlier discussed over noble metals [3,5,18,51]. The symbol * stands for a vacant metallic Pd adsorption site. They essentially differ from the C–H bond scission involving a nearest neighbor vacant site (*) according to step (5(a) or occupied by chemisorbed O atom(step (5(b)). Mechanism I(a) mimics previous DFT calculations on a clean Pd(111) surface taking weakly adsorbed CH4 molecules on a site *-* pairs into account [23]. Indeed, Chin et al. found that the C–H bond breakage proceeds via electron back donation that weakens the C–H bond. On a pre-covered O surface Pd atom-adsorbed oxygen site pairs (*-O*) can be envisioned that would correspond to mechanism I(b). The C–H bond scission involve H abstraction by chemisorbed O* species. Interestingly, the C–H activation bond cleavage would be closely related to the basic character of chemisorbed O* atom. It is worthwhile to note that mechanism I(b) strongly mimics those earlier propose on PdO [7] or on PdO(101) surface [23]. In that case, the heterolytic process for the C–H bond cleavage involves Pd2+ and vicinal O2– site pairs. Electron-back donation from Pd2+ to the anti-bonding molecular orbitals of C–H bond leads to CH3 δ- and Hδ+ stabilized respectively by Pd2+ and O2– [23]. As a matter of fact, the transition state structure is comparable to that calculated on Pd atom-adsorbed oxygen site pairs (*-O*) but higher stabilization on PdO(100) than on Pd(111) leads to lower activation barrier. Theoretical calculations have been implemented for the calculation of the activation barrier as well as the enthalpies for each elementary step according to the Unity Bond Index-Quadratic Exponential Potential method (UBI-QEP) [52]. These calculations took gas phase total bond energy D and atomic heat of chemisorption (Q) into account (see Table S2 in SI). Numerical values performed on a closed-packed Pd(111) surface characterized by preferential three-fold hollow sites are listed in Table S3 in SI. The activation barrier obtained for step (5a) and (5b) of respectively 88 and 117 kJ/mol are calculated at nil coverage θ = 0. Let us note that these values are in agreement with that calculated on Pd(111) considering a surface Pd atom-adsorbed oxygen site pairs (*-O*) or free *-* pairs on bare Pd(111) surface leading to activation barrier of respectively 73 kJ/mol and 117 kJ/mol. Such differences have been explained by repulsions between CH3 and O groups in the transition state inducing destabilization [23]. At first glance, it seems obvious that their comparison invalidates previous assumptions regarding the beneficial role of vicinal O adsorbed species. Strictly, these conditions would be preferentially fullfilled under ultra-high vacuum conditions which strongly differ from our operating conditions as kinetics was studied at atmospheric pressure in an excess of oxygen. In these typical conditions, dynamic processes take place at the surface of active sites and the adsorbate composition is governed by adsorbate–adsorbate interactions and adsorbate-transition state interactions [53]. Hence, the coverage dependence of the adsorbate adsorption strength and the activation energy coverage dependence must be respectively considered in the calculations of energetic parameters. In fact, the adsorbate coverage dependence on the heat of adsorption of methane and oxygen adsorption and activation barrier for steps (5a) and (5b) can be integrated in the calculation with some restriction as the UBI-QEP method only considers mutual interactions between same adsorbates but excludes repulsive or attractive interactions between two different adsorbates. Details on the calculations have been earlier described elsewhere [52]. Hence, the conversion of energetics from the zero converage limit into a coverage dependent bonding energy accounts for a multiplicative scaling factor. Based on this, data in Table 4 illustrate a weakening of the adsorption bond for methane and oxygen with a rise in coverage, respectively θ O and θ C H 4 , assigned to dipole–dipole interactions. This effect becomes significant when 40 % of the adsorption sites are covered which seems plausible in our operating conditions. Activation barrier are also affected by the adsorbate especially step (5b) (CH4* + O* → CH3* + OH*) where chemisorbed O atoms and OH groups appear as reactant and product. As interactions between Oads and OHads are ruled out, data in Table 5 reflect separate O- and OH-coverage dependencies on E f . Interestingly, above θ O = 0.4, the activation barrier for this step becomes lower than that obtained for step 5(a) at nil coverage (87 vs 117 kJ/mol) eventhough the accuracy of the estimates in the range 5–15 kJ/mol must be considered. Hence, the oxygen assistance in C–H bond scission would be restored for θ O ≥ 0.43. On the other hand, antagonistic evolution appears with OH groups as a rise in OH-coverage provokes an increase of the activation barrier reflecting a clear detrimental effect. This kinetic feature provides some arguments which could reasonably explain the loss of conversion observed in the presence of steam due to a strong dissociative adsorption of water on Pd. At low conversion, it is expected that the inhibition should not occur significantly. In our operating conditions, in an excess of oxygen, the O-coverage could be significant. Based on this, mechanism I(b) seems a priori plausible but also undiscernible from earlier mechanism established on PdO where * would represent a Pd2-–O2- site pair as the transition state structure is comparable to that calculated on Pd atom-adsorbed oxygen site pairs (*-O*). The derivation of a rate expression can be easily obtained from mechanism I(b) for further predictions. 4.2.2 Comparison of predicted and experimental rates on a single site reaction mechanism The mathematical expression of predicted reaction rates as a function of the reaction rate constant k n associated to step n, the equilibrium constants for adsorption K A i with Ai = Oads or CH4,ads and the partial pressure of the reactant ( p O 2 and p C H 4 ) can be established for the mechanisms I(b). As argued, by assuming the first C–H bond breaking as slow step then all the others will occur much faster. In case of reversible elementary reactions, they will become quasi equilibrated leading to the expression of surface coverage θ O ∗ and θ CH 4 ∗ respectively O- and methane-coverages and θ v ∗ standing for the fraction of empty sites respectively in Eqs. In fact, Fig. S4 in SI does not invalidate mechanisms I(b) but provides a weak agreement which leads to the conclusion that an alternative reaction mechanism could contribute in parallel. 4.2.3 Single versus dual site reaction mechanism A dual site mechanism I(c) has been envisioned as possible alternative which differs from mechanism I(b) by the nature of reactive oxygen species involved in the C–H bond breaking. It would reflect the cooperation between Pd and the perovskite substrate. Accordingly, surface oxygen species that promote the C–H bond breaking would no longer directly comes from the direct gaseous O2 dissociative adsorption on metallic Pd sites but from surface lattice oxygen supplied from the perovskite thank to the Pd-LaMnO3 interface. Surface XPS analysis emphasizes the coexistence of metallic Pd and PdO oxide species that can also open the discussion on the origin of this oxygen species at the interface as PdO could potentially play the role of supplier of ‘O’ species. The optimized values for kinetic and thermodynamic constants are reported in Table 6 . In all cases the reaction rate constant k16 is much higher than k5 c verifying the previous assumption. The contribution of mechanism I(c) on r predic . has been estimated from these optimized values. First, as general tendency, both mechanisms coexist on pre-reduced catalysts but at various extent as mechanism I(c) would predominate on prereduced Pd/LaMnO3 catalysts whereas mechanism I(b) would prevail on the prereduced LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 catalysts. Interestingly, these contributions vary oppositely after aging and changes are markedly observed on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 for which mechanism I(c) becomes largely predominant after aging. The opposite trend is noticeable on impregnated samples with essentially mechanism I(c) observed on pre-reduced Pd/LaMnO3 catalysts but its contribution diminishes on aged samples with the growth of mechanism I(b). Let us note that these changes occur moderately on Pd/LaMnO3-C800. The extent of such evolutions is in relative agreement with the variations observed on the reaction rate constants k5b and k5c. Indeed, k5b representative of mechanism I(b), involving only palladium, sharply decreases on aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 while k5c representative of the dual reaction mechanism increases in the same extent. The same trends occur on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C800 but appear less pronounced. It is worthwile to note that the values of k5b and k5c slightly changes and evolve in the same direction on aged Pd/LaMnO3-C600 and aged Pd/LaMnO3-C800. Hence, for impregnated samples, the changes in the contribution of mechanism I(c) observed on aged Pd/LaMnO3 should also account for changes in the adsorption properties of palladium reflected by the evolution observed on the equilibrium adsorption constants. This latter point agrees with a possible Pd-PdO transition in the course of the reaction performed in lean conditions then modifying the electronic properties of Pd and its adsorption properties. Clearly different physicochemical processes take place during aging leading to surface reconstruction notably on LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 modifying the nature and the strength of interaction between palladium and the perovskite substrate. The higher contribution of mechanism I(c) on aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 compared to pre-reduced catalyst could be related to higher density of well-dispersed Pd species and the adjustment of the La/Mn ratio recovering the expected value for the perovskite composition. This tendency matches correctly with the increasing values on the pre-exponential factor of the rate constant k. For aged Pd/LaMnO3-C600, the decrease of A can be reasonably explained by Pd particle sintering more accentuated on impregnated samples. On the other hand, the decrease observed on Eapp could have different origin by considering the potential contribution of Pd and PdO. The structure sensitivity of methane combustion over supported Pd catalysts has been previously ascribed to different reactivity of surface oxygen species. As previously emphasized on Pd(111) and PdO(100) surfaces, the Pd-H bond is shortened in the transition state on PdO(100) surface corresponding to improved stabilization of H-atoms. However, the C–H bond breaking appears also sensitive of the surface structure of PdO clusters occurring more readily on PdO(101) than on PdO(100) surface despite the higher stability of this latter one. Such changes have been correlated to significant shift on the activation barrier from 62 kJ/mol vs. 131 kJ/mol on PdO(100) [23]. Based on this the decrease observed on Eapp on aged Pd/LaMnO3 could be tentatively explained by a weakening of the Pd-LaMnO3 interface inducing a weaker stability of metallic Pd species and the growth of larger PdO particles. As explained, the mechanism I(b) cannot differentiate easily the participation of homolytic C–H bond cleavage on a surface Pd atom-adsorbed oxygen site pairs (*-O*) representative of a metallic surface or heterolytic C–H bond cleavage on Pd2+ and vicinal O2– site pairs. On this basis, the decrease explained on Eapp could be equally explained by the deterioration of the Pd-LaMnO3 interface and the participation of Pd2+–O2– site pairs. This explanation in certain extent would also correctly match with the increase of Eapp on aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600. First, the growth of Pd-LaMnO3 interface would contribute in mechanism I(c) but the lower contribution of mechanism I(b) on this catalyst could be equally explained by the higher stability of small PdO particles corresponding to a strengthening of the Pd-O bond inducing weaker interaction between Pd2+ and methyl group in the transition state. Regarding the strong inhibiting of water, it seems unclear to relate their sensibility to the surface structure and the extent of the interface Pd-LaMnO3. Indeed, the presence of water affect all the catalysts in the same extent. As explained, this detrimental effect on the reaction rate is currently assigned to strong water adsorption on PdO leading to stable Pd(OH)2 inhibiting methane adsorption [5,17]. Let us note that UBI-QEP calculations summarized in Table 5 provide complementary informations showing a significant increase of the activation barrier when θ OH exceeds 0.4. It seems plausible that this boundary conditions would be fulfilled in large excess of water inducing a sharp decrease of the rate constant k5b. Another explanation arises based on the aforementioned discussion associated to a preferential neutralization of oxygen species supplied by the perovskite. Shwartz et al. concluded that strong accumulation of OH group could hinder oxygen mobity [54] and suppress the accessibility of ‘O’ species involved in mechanism I(c). Clearly, water inhibition can be explained by kinetic and thermodynamic considerations that are not limited exclusively to PdO. Finally, the evolution observed on the kinetic and thermodynamic parameters meet correctly the evolutions observed on the methane conversion recorded from TPR experiments in lean conditions. The distinct behavior of the impregnated Pd/LaMnO3 and LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 catalysts obtained by sol gel method with respect to deactivation at high temperature in humid conditions is clearly linked to the method used for the incorporation of the Pd appearing as a crucial parameter respectively facilitating the growth of the Pd-LaMnO3 interface or conversely causing a deterioration of this interface. Let us note that these trends are amplified closer to real exhaust conditions. Despite strong inhibiting effects related to the presence of steam and CO2, aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3-C600 exhibits remarkable performances which emphasize more suitable applications in three-way catalysis. 5 Conclusion This study was focused on the effect of the method of Pd addition in Pd-doped LaMnO3 on the kinetic performances for the CH4/O2 reaction performed in lean conditions. One pot synthesis method, leads preferentially to Pd n + species stabilized inside the perovskite lattice when the calcination is performed at 600 °C. At higher temperature, i.e. 800 °C, more reducible extra framework oxidic Pd species form at the surface. For impregnated samples, Pd dispersion is sensitive to the specific surface area with weaker interaction between PdO and LaMnO3. Pre-reduction at 250 °C was performed prior catalytic measurements which does not alter the perovskite structure with preferential formation of metallic Pd sites. Questioning points lie in the evolution of the oxidation state of palladium in the course of the reaction in O2 excess. Changes in structure and surface properties were investigated after exposure at 750 °C in wet atmosphere and the consequence of the kinetics have been discussed by considering the coexistence of Pd covered by chemisorbed O atoms, bulk oxidation to PdO, preferential interaction between Pd and surface lattice oxygen species from the perovskite support corresponding to single and dual sites reaction mechanism in this latter case. This interface Pd-LaMnO3 obeys to some pre-requisites in terms of density of exposed Pd sites at the surface and optimal La/Mn composition reflecting the perovskite composition La/Mn ∼ 1. The exploitation of kinetic measurements at 400 °C led to significant discrepancies as one pot LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 catalysts obey to a single site reaction mechanism while a dual site mechanism emphasizing the cooperation of Pd with surface reactive oxygen species from LaMnO3 and/or PdO would prevail on Pd/LaMnO3. However, the most prominent observations are related to the evolutions induced by thermal aging at 750 °C under wet conditions. Indeed, the contribution of the single site reaction mechanism grows on Pd/LaMnO3 which agrees with the deterioration of the Pd-LaMnO3 interface due to particle sintering. In contrast, the prevalence of dual site mechanism on aged LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 emphasizes the fact that surface reconstructions would strenghen the Pd-LaMnO3 interface. As a matter of fact, this behavior is preferentially characterized when LaMn0.98Pd0.02O3 is originally calcined at 600 °C. Subsequent aging at 750 °C induces moderate ex solution process avoiding particle sintering and the recovery of La/Mn ratio representative of the perovskite composition. Both phenomena would contribute to the build up the Pd-LaMnO3 interface during aging. Catalytic measurements in more representative three-way operating conditions validate the conclusions drawn from the kinetic study in a broader temperature range showing a sharp gain in conversion on aged LaMn0.98Mn0.02O3 ascribed to in situ build up of the Pd-LaMnO3 interface. coredata.dc:description: The kinetics of the CH4/O2 reaction was studied in lean conditions on Natural-Gas-Vehicle Pd-doped LaMnO3 catalysts. The impact of the method for Pd incorporation, sol–gel vs. impregnation, has been examined. The calcination temperature to obtain the perovskite structure turned out to be a key to determine the strength of the interaction between Pd and LaMnO3. Steady-state kinetic measurements at 400 °C have been modeled according to a single site or a dual site reaction mechanism representative of the cooperation between Pd and surface lattice oxygen species supplied by the support material. Impregnated catalysts are found sensitive to particle sintering inducing a deterioration of the metal-support interface. On the contrary, aging leads to strenghening of the metal-support interaction on sol–gel Pd catalysts which promotes methane conversion notably near three-way operating conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Impact of the Pd incorporation method on the kinetics of the CH4/O2 reaction on Natural-Gas-Vehicle model Pd-doped LaMnO3 catalysts
